Incident.Summary: TRAFFIC STOP RESULTING IN DUI ARREST

IncidentSuppNarrative.NarrativeText: *********L-48 EQUIPPED WITH AUDIO/VIDEO EQUIPMENT********* *********INCIDENT CAPTURED ON MVR BODYCAM********* ***NARRATIVE*** On 09/05/2023 at approximately 2352 hrs, I was operating marked MSP unit L-48 on Southbound I-495 in the area of Livingston Road. I observed an Acura SUV pass my patrol vehicle at a high rate of speed. I then observed the grey BMW 540XI (VA AER5652) two lanes over rapidly accelerate to chase after the Acura. I began to pace both vehicles as they traveled side-by-side down Southbound I-495. I paced the two vehicles at speeds up to 120mph in a posted 55mph zone. I observed the BMW swerve from lane 2 into lane 1 nearly striking the rear of another vehicle and the front of the Acura. I activated my emergency equipment and performed a traffic stop on the BMW. The BMW came to a stop on the right shoulder. I approached the passengers side of the BMW and greeted the driver. The driver was identified via his VA drivers license (VA A60113946) as Trent ONeal Dudley (DOB 11/27/1964). I observed Trents eyes to be bloodshot and watery. I detected the odor of an alcoholic beverage emanating from the vehicle. Dudley, when asked why he was speeding stated he was trying to get out of the Acuras way, which is false as the Acura had already passed Dudley as he began to rapidly accelerate. When asked if he had consumed any alcoholic beverages that night Dudley advised he had consumed two drinks of Jameson whiskey at dinner around 2100 hours. I requested Dudley to participate in Standardized Field Sobriety Testing and he agreed. Dudley stated he had reduced vision in his right eye, was on blood pressure medicine, and he had a toe amputated on his left foot which affects his balance. I explained and then demonstrated each of the tests to Dudley before he began. Dudley did not have any questions about any of the tests and he advised that he understood all of the instructions given. The ground used was the asphalt surface of the roadway in front of Dudleys vehicle, which was reasonably level and reasonably free from debris. Before beginning the tests I ensured all emergency vehicles on scene had their front emergency lights turned off. Now away from the vehicle, I continued to smell the odor of an alcoholic beverage emanating from Dudleys breath and person. Horizontal Gaze Nystagmus 6 of 6 clues Dudleys eyes were bloodshot and watery. Both eyes tracked equally and both pupils were equally sized. Dudley exhibited the following clues: - Lack of smooth pursuit in both eyes - Distinct and sustained nystagmus at maximum deviation in both eyes - Onset of nystagmus prior to 45 degrees in both eyes Walk and Turn 5 of 8 clues - Didnt touch heel to toe multiple times - Stepped off line multiple times - Took 4 steps on second set of steps. - Used arms for balance, placed them on his hips a few times and raised them from sides more than 6 inches - Stopped walking repeatedly, restarted test after every mistake One Leg Stand 3 of 4 clues - Swayed from side to side while balancing - Used arms for balance. - Put foot down multiple times Throughout testing Dudley became frustrated with his performance and repeatedly stated he was going to fail the tests. Dudley was arrested at 0013 hrs on 09/06/2023 and transported to MSP Forestville for processing. Once at MSP Forestville, Dudley elected to listen to an English audio recording of the DR15. Dudley was given a blank copy of the DR15 form to follow along. Once Dudley was finished listening to the DR15 he advised that he wanted to take the intoximeter breath test. Dudley signed the DR15 at 0049 hrs on 07/06/2023. Dudley was provided with a copy of the DR15 and DR15a. Sgt Estrin #6052, a certified Intoximeter Breath Tech, demonstrated and operated the Intoximeter breath test for Dudley. Dudley provided a sufficient breath sample of .13BrAC. at approximately 0102 hrs on 07/06/2023. Dudley was cited the appropriate citations. Dudley was released from MSP Forestville to a sober driver shortly after processing was complete. All events occurred in Prince Georges County, Maryland.
